title.narrative: LGBT+ inclusive approaches to conflict and the WPS agenda

description.narrative:
International Alert will create three reflection workshops in Myanmar and Nepal comprising the LGBT community, women’s rights activists and youth to reflect on their experiences, strengthen connections and build capacity between groups, and develop key advocacy messages targeting local stakeholders.
Alert will share key advocacy messages with a wider national audience through radio shows in both countries and TV engagement in Nepal. Participants in Myanmar will design a social media campaign to challenge gender norms and prevent GBV.
Finally, we will conduct a comparative analysis of Myanmar and Nepal to provide an insight into the deficiencies of LGBT programming to inform and improve future GBV programme design. Alert’s Gender team will also include the lessons and recommendations in its framework to counter patriarchal norms and masculinities.
Kings N Queens (Myanmar) and Federation of Sexual and Gender Minorities (Nepal)

LGBT community – the needs and perspectives of the LGBT community have been represented in the design and planning of the project by our partners, Kings N Queens and Federation of Sexual and Gender Minorities, who maintain active networks of LGBT community-based organisations and are best placed to express the needs and to identify entry points for LGBT programming in their respective countries. The proposal reflects their needs by orientating itself around them: identifying its targets through a needs assessment, developing workshops to facilitate reflection on their context and designing advocacy actions to help change it, and producing a policy document to improve the capture of LGBT issues within WPS programming.

The project aims to promote the inclusion of LGBT voices in Women, Peace and Security (WPS) programming through context analysis, capacity building and advocacy in Myanmar and Nepal, and will contribute to ongoing advocacy efforts transforming discriminatory patriarchal gender norms and masculinities.
